body:
Generally - looks good and I think we do want to continue improving the java-jsonld usage. 

While [JENA-1948](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/JENA-1948) proposes using Titanium, I, for one, don't know if Titanium is fast/slow/good/bad. If they have different pros and cons, having both is possible.
Ping @fpservant

> as far as I can follow the changes

Yes! Dispatch, in all its cases and all its extensibility is complicated. It's been though a number of rewrites. The test coverage is good and that has been essential in this PR which is a simplification of the dispatch process.

Thanks to you both for looking.
Enough to make it worth getting into the codebase.

Here are all the files over 10M produced by a Jena build to look at all the places GraalVM gets picked up by bundling:

No GraalVM about 245M:
```

```

```

 93M    apache-jena-fuseki/3.17.0-SNAPSHOT/apache-jena-fuseki-3.17.0-SNAPSHOT.tar.gz

 14M    jena-elephas-stats/3.17.0-SNAPSHOT/jena-elephas-stats-3.17.0-SNAPSHOT-hadoop-job.jar
```

Note the appearance of jena-elephas-stats

The unpacked "apache-jena" goes from 25M to 63M.
@afs so what about Docker Hub? Is the plan to get the images to build automatically?
That is explained in the description on the JIRA ticket.

Final cleanup before merging. 

Comments for download.sh and in Dockerfile.
Fix in README for "docker build".
Split curl arguments for clarity.
Thanks for the license header updates.

Adding GraalVM is the way to go because Jena gets multiple languages for writing extensions, as well as supporting Javascript which is there are the moment.

It is a large increase in size and,by default, will get included in all combined binaries - this includes downstream users who, judging by the slow but steady stream of questions on StackOverflow, do produce shaded jars of their systems with all Jena dependencies.

Proposal:

For the moment, make GraalVM optional.

1. Have the code look for GraalVM and if not found, look for Hashhorn. 
1. Make GraalVM <optional> in the jena-arq POM, then it won't be picked up downstream.
1. Start to point out that this is going to happen at some version.
Both Nashorn and GraalVM-based JavaScript engine are available under the alias "javascript"; GraalVM unregisters Nashorn if both are present. So we can just look for "javascript".

License issues on dev@jena.

I didn't properly grok that while graalvm.js has a category-A license, the graalvm engine is a different license.

This is useful stuff, and I have no objections by any means. Question: is this how you expect ideas for a new API to be presented? Via a "sidecar" library of functions like this? I'm inspired to ask because I see a number of things like "return a param or a default" which would make a lot of sense to impl via returning `Optional` from a hypothetical new graph abstraction.

@ajs6f 

> Question: is this how you expect ideas for a new API to be presented?

I don't have preference. This is a bit different as it is, mostly, moved from `jena-shacl`.  This library also "parked" in a not-API place for the moment so it can be morphed.

`Graph` is a bit different because it is the base of all RDF access. I would have expected a new API to build on top of `Graph` in the same way that `Model` does.

Actually changing `Graph` to add a whole bunch of operations and across different style of API does not seem like a good idea.

Specifically for `G`, it really is adding words to more accurately describe what it going on so even where the operations are one liners, I think it clearer to give the pattern a descriptive name. Other operations wrap up a bit of checking so moving visiual clutter out of the caller app. YMMV.

Added

- comments for nearly all public functions.
- `Objects.requiresNonNull`
- rename variables e.g. `s` -> `subject`

@afs whew! Finally got all the features "working" â„¢. It needs some further testing to see what is working as before, what needs changing, etc.

Could you take a look later, whenever you have time (no hurry :+1:).

Once we are OK with the new app, I'll start writing tests, as normally a few bugs pop when you shake the JavaScript code too hard :grin: 

And after that the final step would then be to look at the Maven build (where I would need more help).

Cheers
Bruno
I'll be delighted to try it out.  How do I build it?

When you check out this branch, start FusekiCmd (fuseki2). I start it in Eclipse with no extra params.

You should have Fuseki Backbone.js UI available on localhost:3030. I used this to compare with new UI.

Now in the new module folder (jena-fuseki-ui) run `yarn install` which will install the dependencies from npmjs.com (js equivalent to maven central).

Now `yarn run serve` should start a dev server on localhost:8080. The dev server has also a proxy to send requests to localhost:3030 (that's why you need to initialize that one too).

And now just compare the two versions side by side.

https://yarnpkg.com/
https://docs.npmjs.com

Thanks!
Bruno

(Does not affect this PR) 
when checking the details, I found some Java code constants for TriG make it look like the correct MIME type is `text/trig`, not application/trig`. Both work through out the system so it's not observable - it's just the constant naming and `Lang` definition. I'll tidy this up.

> process and processTTL looks similar, but I couldn't think of any way to simplify further the code.

Yes - they do look the same and when I came back to them for this ticket I thought - "missed that last time". But they are not the same with differences throughout.

I was going on the tick list - let's get something in.

For jena-fuseki-webapp, the code looks OK as it is for this and a good step forward.

We can worry about Fuseki/main later. I have thought a bit about how to add administration functions but not written anything down. It is a chance to do things a bit differently to Fuseki/Webapp, around the fixed area which isn't so convenient for remote administration and also whether it can be simpler and making it opt-in, not always there. But later.

The build failure is an artifact of Travis.
It has passed (same commit) on a different Travis account.

(The ASF GH/Travis integration is work-in-progress at the moment - and a lot of projects are triggering builds)

This facility would be good to have.   Would it be possible to incorporate into the main Dockerfile? That way, as the fine tuning of the docker container operation are in one place and, given this module is new, there may well be suggestions for improvements.

Doe sit need to pull the tarball and not the jar file? The Dockerfile works with Fuseki Main (jena-fuseki-server).

There is combined jar for Fuseki/webapp (with UI) in jena-fuseki-fulljar but I don't think anyone has tested the file system layout with this form.

The top-level question is whether this adds benefit to the user community. Our user community is diverse, some people are highly skilled developers, and some are highly skilled data experts who use programming as a means to an end (and may work in several languages).

`Txn` is public API and I don't think it helps to remove it.

Adding default methods that call `Txn.XYZ` would be good.

I also think that the traditional style begin/commit, ideally inside try-finally is what many users are familiar with, either because of JDBC experience or not really having adopted in their java the lambda functional style in their own code.

So my preference is add the default methods as calls to Txn, and have the Transactional javadoc be fairly neutral in opinion (I'll adds some review comments).

It could be implemented into the main Dockerfile, but would have to introduce conditionals for the default REPO arg and tarball extraction, which seemed messy, so I split it into separate one.

I will try with the JAR, didn't know about the jar directory

> Adding default methods that call `Txn.XYZ` would be good.

I'm not sure actually. Calling `Txn` from `Transactional` would introduce a circular dependency between them, which is not nice, especially because they belong to different packages.

Any idea if 5.0.0 -> 6.0.0 is any major difference that will affect Jena usage?
6.0.0 is pretty old - 2014 - so presuming everyone is using this one anyway.

> Does this constitute a breaking change (either at the API level or behavioural)?

No.

`Dataset.getPrefixMapping()` has a default method.

`DatasetGraph` does have a new interface method. We could add a default impl but at the moment, it signals "take note" to any downstream implementations I don't know about.

There is no intention to break or change any behaviour where code has not been unwrapping classes and directly getting at the TDB1/TDB2 prefix storage. But that's cheating anyway :-).

It is a big internal change. One reason for putting in right at the start of a version cycle is to give it maximum shakedown and to give downstream systems as much chance as possible to test. I know of very few cases of prefixes not being used as "parse in to set, write out to use".
Thank you for the reviews. I've fixed the javadoc comments and squashed it down locally to a single commit which, if nothing else, aids reversing this should any problems arise.
The validation build has passed on my branch-build on travis-ci.org.

I think that's a fair assumption. Karaf only recently changed to OSGi 7, so updating to v6 should be no problem at all (Karaf has been on v6 for as long as I can remember). As discussed earlier, upgrading at the beginning of a release series means that we have more time to catch any regressions.

I get the same warning as with 5.0.0:
```
[WARNING] Bundle org.apache.jena:jena-osgi:bundle:3.18.0-SNAPSHOT : osgi.serviceloader capability found with no 'register:' directive. Descriptor cannot be managed for osgi.serviceloader;osgi.serviceloader="org.apache.commons.rdf.api.RDF"
```
Is this an upstream issue?
If I am not mistaken, we're done. Please let me know if this is not the case. Cheers!

Additionally, I've had to implement a kind of non-invasive visitor pattern to process constraint structures (such as sh:or/sh:node): 
https://github.com/researchstudio-sat/webofneeds/blob/feat-acl-impl/webofneeds/won-utils/won-utils-shacl2java/src/main/java/won/shacl2java/constraints/ConstraintVisitor.java

Of course, I would have preferred to use visitor methods offered by the Constraint classes. If you are interested, I can modify my implementation and add the visitor methods and visitor interface to the jena classes in a separate PR.

Seeing a PR for the visitor pattern would be interesting.

Sometimes it take time to get round to PRs when there are several in-progress. This week has been getting in the ones that are best done at the beginning of a release cycle.
The build passed so it looks OK and I don't see anything changed in the build log test run.

ValueRangeConstraint and ConstraintPairwise - have two getters for the same thing. `Constraint` already has `getComponent`.

I've removed the stray.
Please could you put the vitro in a consistent place in the constraints? Just before printCompact would be fine as many of them are there already.

I am unsure that default methods on the visitor are the way to go. An abstract class "ConstraintBase" has been the style up until Java8 and now can have a mixin/trait to do the same.

Reason: robustness.

When writing complex visitors it is good to have a way for the programmer to know they have covered all cases and be notified when a new constraint is added. Otherwise it is possible to miss a case and compile time and and it becomes a runtime problem.

Leaving this as draft for the moment ... to think about whether any other cases will cause damage to the system.

It does apply in all settings (e.g. plain RDFDataset for an inference model over TDB2) but the text dataset is a wrapper layer on the base storage - much simpler.

Other cases that might prove difficult are where some sort of view/union is used across multiple distinct dataset.  However I think it's fine that the answer for that case is to provide another service that directly exposes the lower level dataset

Yes! This isn't all cases.

If the dataset does not fit the unwrapping algorithm, it does not find a TDB2.

It is only where one dataset wraps a single other dataset, not across multiple distinct datasets. An example of the lkatter not covered is inference and there, I agree, exposing the base dataset makes sense.
Rebased. Reading e-mail threads about this issue, and also about "Future Fuseki Admin API Thought", to see if I can come up with a solution for the Maven build here.

I think this may work... the current `jena-fuseki-webapp` stays as-is for now. Later we may split it into "view" and "admin" modules.

The `jena-fuseki-ui` will produce HTML, JS, CSS, image, etc., assets into `jena-fuseki-ui/target/dist/`.

Andâ€”somehow, still thinking howâ€”`jena-fuseki-war` will include `jena-fuseki-webapp` as dependency, bringing the servlets, and using its `web.xml`; while also copying the assets of `jena-fuseki-ui` into its WAR webapp folder (currently it's using `jena-fuseki-webapp`'s `webapp` contents, including the old BackboneJS application).

![jena-drawing](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/304786/102003645-93c83300-3d6e-11eb-9210-dc94f8a31bf6.png)

Last commit has a WIP of the suggested design above. But he log4j and other configuration files are missing from the generated war, and not sure if the parent module that uses the assembly plugin to produce the ZIP and tar.gz files is working correctly.

Alright, last commit of night. Tried to update the assembly file to use the files from `jena-fuseki-ui`. It generated the correct webapp files, and includes the log4j configuration file. Just need to find time to test it, and see if it's deployed correctly to Tomcat. :sleeping_bed:
There are some functions copied - the exceptions are different (QueryParseException vs RiotParseException) - except I missed this function so updated to RiotParseException.

What is more mockito isn't a dependency of jena-elephas.

It comes (no PR):
```
[INFO] \- org.apache.mrunit:mrunit:jar:hadoop2:1.1.0:test
[INFO]    +- org.mockito:mockito-core:jar:1.9.5:test
```
(mrunit only runs on Java8, not later anyway)

but with the dependency mechanism seems to drag in as 3.2.28 which I can't explain.
Simple answer is to specify it directly in jena-elephas just to keep Java8 alive.

Seems to work (Java8) with the latest push. Forces the version of mockito to agree with mrunit, not jena elsewhere.

(It all might work anyway because there is also a initialization/start-up issue that showed up when dependencies changed.)
